dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Shang-Hua, it's so great to see you again. I think last time we met was in 2017 or something like that.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think we Zoomed once during the pandemic, but it's good to see you in person.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Right. Absolutely.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: And actually, in '86 I was taking a crypto class with Professor Leonard Edelman, the A of RSA. And he assigned me the paper by Goldwasser, Micali, and Charlie Rackoff on zero-knowledge proof. So that's indeed my first ever presentation, ever, in this country.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Was about zero-knowledge. That's awesome.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: [Shang-Hua] Was about zero-knowledge, yes.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It's such a almost hypnotic concept.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It's also an interesting way how mathematically to formulate those concepts, right. For example, we have data. Then eventually we started from data, like data mining, you can get the information, and then you have this word called knowledge.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [Amit] Right

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Right. So knowledge has been long debated, even in philosophy. What is knowledge?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Indeed.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: But here is a very fascinating way mathematicians or computer scientists

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: want to somehow capture this knowledge. It didn't say zero-information proof.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [Amit] Right.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So what's your take on why knowledge is, rather than information, or zero-data proof. Clearly, there's data there. So can't be zero-data.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Absolutely. I don't think we still have a completely satisfactory answer to that question. What was so, such a beautiful insight, as I'm sure you know, is that the idea of zero-knowledge

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: being something that you can already predict. Right.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: If you can already predict the answer, then you must not be gaining any knowledge by that interaction. This insight of being able to predict the future accurately, and that being an evidence of a lack of new knowledge,

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: [Shang-Hua] Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: was such a beautiful insight, such an amazing insight.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Well there's not zero-information here. Fundamentally I, clearly from computing perspective, security perspective, is how much knowledge you're gaining, I guess. More than how much information you've gained.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Indeed.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: And how much data you have. Right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So that data then immediately imply, a knowledge. But people can't, sometimes.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Right. Sometimes. I mean, for example, in medical research, how amazing would it be, right, to be able to have a drug, and be able to prove that my drug works in this model.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And yet, not have to actually reveal the structure of the compound.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: What, currently, you're saying it would be the next directions in this space.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What's the next big things?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah. This concept of zero-knowledge programs would allow you to carry out completely arbitrary computations

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: in a zero-knowledge way, without any interaction, right. I can just take the program, convert it to a zero-knowledge program, or an obfuscated program, and then just send it to you.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And then you can run it and gain the benefit of that computation without having to talk to me anymore.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's right. There's a non-interactive nature.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [Amit] The non-interactive nature.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: But there's verifiability in it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Indeed.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Sometimes when, for example, when you have multi-protocol exchange that, you know, just like a random number showed up, you have to enter the random number.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: As authentication, yes.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Authentication, right. Now clearly I think in block chain, they also began to incorporate a more

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Indeed.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: general knowledge of proof in the ledger.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: We're definitely at this moment now, where zero-knowledge is gonna be used more and more. There are so many conferences and meetings that occur in the zero-knowledge space, where you and I are not invited. Because it's for the people who are developing. You know, the people who are programming, not us mathematicians.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: [Shang-Hua] Yes, yes.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And I think that's a sign. That's a sign that our baby has grown up and, you know, it's time for it to be developed.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think, profoundly, the students often also ask me, what are the future direction, both in terms of crypto, zero-knowledge proof, in the real world and how mathematical you see in computing.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It's a great question. I wish I could see the future. I can't actually, but let me try. The part of that that I'm the most comfortable answering is of course the mathematical side.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I think that there is, you know, we've done so much in cryptography over the last few decades, but we understand so little.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: You know, even today we understand so little. And I think the most fundamental aspect of that is understanding hardness. How do we get hard problems?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: How do we actually build mathematically hard problems so that we can then use them to build efficient zero-knowledge programs.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: [Shang-Hua] Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And efficient zero-knowledge proofs, right?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I guess also, in quantum computing, you need even harder problems.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Indeed. Absolutely. You know, now that we have the specter of quantum computing

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: [Shang-Hua] Yes, yes.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: coming at us and we all know that quantum computers can break a lot of cryptographic systems.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yes. A profound challenge.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It's a profound challenge. So can we find new sources of hardness that are quantum-resistant?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: [Shang-Hua] That's right.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: But I'm sure they will motivate beautiful mathematics.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That even quantum computers can't break. And that's something I've been working on for the last several years. But I'd be very excited to see what happens in that space.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yes, that's right. You know, one of the great things about the real world is that people in the real world have demands.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And those demands often sound impossible. And that's where we come in. It's our job to make the impossible possible.
